confession.seduction_context: Husband was at tavern in Sainte Croix for up to 2 days, leaving her alone. Seduced on one of these occasions when she went searching for him or had to return alone late at night. She tried to say she wanted to keep right to return to God later. Devil promised money but after intercourse in field left without giving money or powder. Later took her to feast with other accomplices.
powder_types: powder from master to throw over victims

testimony.quarrel_subject: child picked up fallen plum from garden of accused's husband

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: soon after - became ill, died a year later

testimony.threat_quote: avoit tant faict que jamais n'yroit par chemin

witnesses.name: Andress Huraldei
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: community member - struck accused with cutlass

testimony.quarrel_subject: comments about Remy Couppebois when he was ill
testimony.threat_quote: que jamais ledit Remy Couppebois n'en auroit aultre jusques a la mort

testimony.quarrel_subject: debt owed by accused's husband - summoned before maire for payment
testimony.threat_quote: que le Diable soit a ses bras, jambes et a son corps

harms_alleged.target: his crops in plot adjoining those of accused's husband

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: when he came down from tree taking cherries

testimony.quarrel_subject: taking horse to woods behind accused's house

testimony.threat_quote: qu'elle n'avoit pas encor assez lainguy et qu'il la convenoit davantage lainguir tant que les chiens piseroient contre elle

timeline.subject: Denisatte femme Nicolas Humbert
timeline.details: Seven witnesses testified. Document notes she had already been interrogated after denunciation by Appoline femme Balthazar Belz but refused to confess.

timeline.subject: Denisatte femme Nicolas Humbert
timeline.details: Gave biographical details. Confessed to seduction by maitre Folland 8 years before, attendance at feast with accomplices. Refused to confess to maleficia. Sent back to prison.

timeline.subject: Denisatte femme Nicolas Humbert
timeline.details: Was read depositions of witnesses. Said she held them for gens de bien but denied guilt. Mentioned that she and Jeanne femme Allois Humbert had been seen spinning in field at dusk 18 months earlier when Folland appeared wanting intercourse and to give herbs, but they refused. Would confess nothing else. Sent back to prison with threats of torture.

timeline.subject: Denisatte femme Nicolas Humbert
timeline.details: Denied at first but when torture began begged to be set down to confess. Confessed to using herbs and powder from master to harm Remy Couppebois, Jeanne Joliat, and Guillaume Tarrat. Did not want to confess anything else.

timeline.subject: Denisatte femme Nicolas Humbert
timeline.details: Sentenced to death by burning alive

accomplices_named.name: Jeanne femme Allois Humbert
accomplices_named.context: Seen with accused spinning in field at dusk some 18 months before trial. Maitre Folland appeared to both wanting intercourse and to give herbs, but they refused.

prior_accusations.context: Had denounced accused, leading to earlier interrogation where accused refused to confess

notable_quotes.speaker: Denisatte to Remy Couppebois
notable_quotes.french: avoit tant faict que jamais n'yroit par chemin
notable_quotes.english: had done so much that he would never go by road/path again
notable_quotes.context: Said about Remy Couppebois in house of Lienard l'Hoste, after which Andress Huraldei struck her with cutlass

notable_quotes.speaker: Andress Huraldei to Denisatte
notable_quotes.french: meschante genoxe fault il qu'a ton occasion l'homme de bien la n'aille plus par chemin
notable_quotes.english: wicked witch, must it be that because of you the good man no longer goes by the road
notable_quotes.context: Said when striking her with cutlass after her comment about Remy Couppebois

notable_quotes.speaker: Colas Humbert (accused's husband)
notable_quotes.french: Quiconque vouldroit parler dudit Remy que c'estoit des schelmes et des meschantes hommes
notable_quotes.english: Whoever would speak of said Remy, that they were scoundrels and wicked men
notable_quotes.context: Said when people started talking about Remy Couppebois when he was ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Denisatte to Colas Humbert
notable_quotes.french: que jamais ledit Remy Couppebois n'en auroit aultre jusques a la mort
notable_quotes.english: that said Remy Couppebois would never have other/better until death
notable_quotes.context: Added after husband's comment defending Remy

notable_quotes.speaker: Denisatte to Guillaume Tarrat
notable_quotes.french: que le Diable soit a ses bras, jambes et a son corps
notable_quotes.english: may the Devil be at his arms, legs and his body
notable_quotes.context: Said when she found him taking cherries from garden where her husband had fruit rights

notable_quotes.speaker: Denisatte to Jeanne femme Joliat
notable_quotes.french: Caigne, je te feray manger des chiens et des porcs
notable_quotes.english: Dog/bitch, I will make you be eaten by dogs and pigs
notable_quotes.context: About 8 years before; Jeanne died after languishing and would have been eaten by animals if not prevented

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbelline and household
notable_quotes.french: qu'ilz pouvoient bien faire bonne chere, et que de longtemps ilz n'en auroient tant
notable_quotes.english: that they could well feast/make good cheer, and that for a long time they would not have so much
notable_quotes.context: Accused's response when Barbelline said by grace of God they had enough grain for the year; after which their wheat never did well

notable_quotes.speaker: Denisatte to Jeanne (mother of Jean Joliat)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle n'avoit pas encor assez lainguy et qu'il la convenoit davantage lainguir tant que les chiens piseroient contre elle
notable_quotes.english: that she had not yet languished enough and that she should languish more until the dogs pissed against her
notable_quotes.context: Said when dying woman called out 'Commere Denisatte' hoping for help; as many testified, this happened

relationships.evidence_text: Both have surname Humbert, likely related
her husband had owed him money (as he still did)

economic_context.details: Husband Nicolas Humbert owed money to Guillaume Tarrat for at least 16 years; Tarrat summoned him before maire to get payment. Dispute over fruit rights in garden led to conflict. Husband frequented taverns in Sainte Croix where he would spend up to 2 days, suggesting some disposable income but also marital stress. Accused's economic status appears poor based on: (1) prolonged unpaid debt, (2) husband's tavern habits leaving her alone, (3) no mention of property ownership, (4) seduction narrative mentions devil promised money, suggesting need.

harms_catalog.method_alleged: herbs in apple given when he asked for something to refresh him (confession)

harms_catalog.harm_description: died etique (wasting disease) with something hard around neck, after illness lasting about a year
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: child picked up fallen plum from garden of accused's husband; threatened by husband, chased by accused
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: became ill soon after, died a year later

harms_catalog.harm_description: wheat never did well after accused's comment
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Barbelline said by grace of God they had enough grain for year; accused said they could feast but for long time wouldn't have so much

harms_catalog.harm_description: crops in plot adjoining those of accused's husband laid waste by storm, while their crops unharmed
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: debt - Tarrat summoned husband before maire for payment; Denisatte told him he would repent

harms_catalog.harm_description: as if rabid and out of his senses, lasted 2 years during which unable to earn by working
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: found him taking cherries from garden where her husband had fruit rights; cursed him
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: when he came down from tree
harms_catalog.method_alleged: powder from master thrown over him (confession)

harms_catalog.harm_description: languished a long time 'soubs ladite assuée', would have been eaten by animals if not prevented
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jeanne told accused that her husband had been to devin (cunning person) and on return spoke much evil of them
harms_catalog.method_alleged: herbs in bread to make her languish and die (confession)

harms_catalog.harm_description: lying ill, languished until dogs pissed against her as accused predicted
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: called out 'Commere Denisatte' hoping for help but accused cursed her instead

harms_catalog.harm_description: sickened, becoming thinner the more it ate, died after 5 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: threatened he would repent if continued to take horse to woods behind their house
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: soon after threat, took no notice

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow and calf of Henry Maigrat
harms_catalog.harm_description: died in same manner as horse
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: same as horse - using woods behind their house

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial is well-documented with clear witness testimony and confession details. Key uncertainties: (1) Exact relationship between Nicolas Humbert and Allois Humbert unclear - likely family but not explicitly stated. (2) Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on prolonged unpaid debt, husband's tavern habits leaving wife alone, and devil's promise of money, though accused household had some resources (fruit rights, access to taverns). (3) No information about Change de Nancy consultation - appears to be local court decision only. (4) The term 'etique' for child's illness likely refers to wasting disease/consumption. (5) 'soubs ladite assuée' is unclear terminology - may refer to specific condition or curse. (6) Two witnesses (5 and 7) both mention Jeanne femme Joliat's death, providing corroboration. (7) Torture method not specified beyond standard procedure. (8) No execution date given, only sentence date. (9) Grand Rombach vs Grand Romberg appears to be spelling variation of same place.
